instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-01521: What is 820-01521? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP3V3_G3H_RTC: What is PP3V3_G3H_RTC? PP3V3_G3H_RTC Is one of the first rails that has to come on in order for the USB-C mux chip to be powered in the T2 chip Macbook Pros..
definitions.PP0V9_SSD: What is PP0V9_SSD? PP0V9_SSD is a power rail that powers the soldered on NAND memory for the SSD on Macbooks with soldered on storage and must be present for the SSD to show up. .
definitions.PP2V7_NAND: What is PP2V7_NAND? PP2V7_NAND is a power rail that powers the soldered on NAND memory for the SSD on Macbooks with soldered on storage and must be present for the SSD to show up. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01521</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> MacBook Air first 5v stuck, now 20v but DFU error
threads.message:
Hello, sorry mi English. 
This is a <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01521</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> MacBook Air that  came not turning on whit 5v stuck. Connected the mac in DFU mode and apply a revive option but shows the [U]75 error[/U] . Now the usb meter register 20v but in DFU mode have the same issue.
In some YouTube video saw that maybe the issue was the SSD so i check the rails and only <SIGNAL>PP2V7_NAND</SIGNAL> seems low (2.5V)

<SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H_RTC</SIGNAL> =3.3v
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> = 12.56v

[U]<CHIP>U8600</CHIP>/<CHIP>U8607</CHIP>[/U]
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_SSD</SIGNAL> = 1.8V
<SIGNAL>PP2V7_NAND</SIGNAL> = 2.5V (Seems low)
<SIGNAL>PP0V9_SSD</SIGNAL> = 0.9V
<SIGNAL>SSD0_S4E0_VPP</SIGNAL> = 2.1V 
<SIGNAL>SSD0_S4E1_VPP</SIGNAL> = 2.1V
<SIGNAL>SSD0_RESET_L</SIGNAL> = 1.8V
<SIGNAL>SSD0_S4E0_PCI_AVDD_H</SIGNAL> = 1.8V

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01521</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> MacBook Air first 5v stuck, now 20v but DFU error
threads.message:
Any history available, liquid sign?

What you did to get 20V on USB meter now?
Tried DFU with charger and battery, both connected?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01521</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> MacBook Air first 5v stuck, now 20v but DFU error
threads.message:
Came from another workshop, but no sigs off corrosion or work on the motherboard.
The battery seems death,I will find another to test again

I didn't do anything special to get the 20v. When it arrived, I used the usb tester and it had 5v, then I removed the tester and put the mac in DFU mode and when it recognized it, I tried the revive option without success. Then I tried the tester again and it was 20v.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01521</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> MacBook Air first 5v stuck, now 20v but DFU error
threads.message: You can try DFU restore; data is lost anyway, I suppose.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01521</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> MacBook Air first 5v stuck, now 20v but DFU error
threads.message: When trying to restore I have a different error and it does not complete the process :(

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01521</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> MacBook Air first 5v stuck, now 20v but DFU error
threads.message:
SSD failure is possible.
Just in case, inspect audio board/flex and touch ID for corrosion.
